name: Department of the Interior
description: The Department of the Interior protects and manages the Nation's natural resources and cultural heritage, provides scientific and other information about those resources, and honors its trust responsibilities to American Indians, Alaska Natives, and affiliated island communities.

budget.procurementBudget: $14.7 billion annually (average FY2020-2023 in grants and contracts)

painPoints.point: Deferred maintenance crisis - backlog grew from $170 billion in 2017 to $370 billion in 2024
painPoints.source: GAO-25-108028 Federal Real Property Report & GAO High-Risk Series 2025

painPoints.point: High risk of fraud and mismanagement in grants and contracts due to inadequate internal controls and oversight
painPoints.source: DOI Office of Inspector General FY2025 Budget - Data Analytics Unit findings

painPoints.point: Cybersecurity vulnerabilities - malicious actors continue to present risks to Federal systems and critical infrastructure
painPoints.source: DOI FY2025 Budget in Brief - FBMS Zero Trust Architecture

painPoints.point: Wildfire crisis intensifying due to climate change requiring expanded workforce and aviation contracts
painPoints.source: DOI FY2024 Budget - Wildfire Management $1.33 billion allocation

painPoints.point: Challenges deploying Bipartisan Infrastructure Law funding promptly while maintaining staffing capacity and program controls
Difficulty accurately and reliably estimating deferred maintenance costs across bureaus
painPoints.source: DOI Office of Inspector General oversight findings FY2024

painPoints.point: IT consolidation challenges - implementing enterprise-wide Tier 1 and Tier 2 service standardization across bureaus
painPoints.source: Federal News Network IT Consolidation Report September 2025

painPoints.point: Lifecycle investment approach implementation gaps - transitioning from reactive to preventive maintenance
painPoints.source: DOI FY2025 Budget - $2.7 billion lifecycle management allocation

painPoints.point: IT acquisition and management challenges including project delays, budget overruns, and need for improved oversight and mature acquisition practices affecting federal real property and land management IT systems
painPoints.source: GAO High-Risk List 2025 - Improving IT Acquisitions and Management

strategicPriorities.priority: Wildland fire management expansion - $1.33 billion for preparedness, aviation contracts, and tribal support
Deferred maintenance reduction and lifecycle asset management - $2.7 billion for real property
strategicPriorities.source: DOI FY2025 Budget & GAO Federal Real Property Report

strategicPriorities.priority: Tribal climate resilience and relocation support - $440 million investment through BIL and IRA
IT modernization and zero trust architecture implementation for Financial and Business Management System (FBMS)
strategicPriorities.funding: $57.8 million for FBMS operations and security upgrades

strategicPriorities.priority: IT consolidation across bureaus - enterprise service standardization and quality control
Buy Indian Act procurement expansion for tribal vendors across BIA, BIE, and AS-IA
strategicPriorities.source: Bureau of Indian Affairs Buy Indian Act Primer 2025

strategicPriorities.priority: Acquisition oversight enhancement - improved controls for $14.7B annual grant and contract spending
strategicPriorities.source: DOI OIG FY2025 Budget - Financial Management Oversight (+3 FTE)

secondary: Federal News Network IT Consolidation Report September 2025
BIA Buy Indian Act Primer - https://www.bia.gov/sites/default/files/dup/assets/as-ia/ieed/Primer on Buy Indian Act 508 Compliant 2.6.18(Reload).pdf

setAsidePreferences.smallBusiness: Strong preference - actively seeks small business participation
setAsidePreferences.8a: Regular use for environmental and infrastructure services
setAsidePreferences.HUBZone: Active use - many DOI locations in HUBZones
setAsidePreferences.BuyIndian: Mandatory preference for tribal vendors under Buy Indian Act

typicalContractSizes.large: $50M - $500M+ (major construction, IT modernization, multi-year wildfire management)

prefers: Environmental and natural resource management expertise
Facilities construction and deferred maintenance capabilities
IT modernization and cybersecurity (zero trust architecture)
Tribal engagement and Buy Indian Act eligibility
procurementCharacteristics.contractingTimeline: 6-24 months average (longer for major infrastructure), expedited for wildfire emergencies
procurementCharacteristics.competitionLevel: Moderate to high - specialized expertise required, strong tribal vendor preference
evaluationFactors: Past performance with DOI or natural resource agencies

keyOffices: Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement (OSMRE)
Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement (BSEE)
insights: $370 billion deferred maintenance backlog represents enormous multi-decade construction and infrastructure opportunity
Wildfire management is urgent priority with $1.33B annual spending including aviation contracts and tribal support
Buy Indian Act creates mandatory set-aside pathway for tribal vendors - significant competitive advantage
GAO identified DOI real property as high-risk area since 2003 - sustained oversight and reform pressure
$14.7B annual contract spending vulnerable to fraud per OIG - increased compliance and oversight contracts likely
Tribal climate resilience $440M investment creates opportunities for environmental consulting and infrastructure
IT consolidation across 10 bureaus represents multi-year modernization contracts
Bipartisan Infrastructure Law deployment challenges create need for program management and controls expertise
Zero trust architecture cybersecurity implementation is mandatory priority for all IT systems
GSA Acquisition Gateway now hosts DOI forecast - check annually in October for updated opportunities
